pageContext.description:
The woodcut showing 'Luther as Junker Jörg' is the last graphic portrait of Luther by Cranach. and marked his return to the public stage in 1522. It was widely disseminated and continued to be printed until late into the 16th century. The inscription celebrates Luther's return employing the island of Patmos (where St John wrote the Apocalypse) as a metaphor for his time at the Wartburg.
This edition must have appeared before Luther's final return to Wittenberg, to which allusion is made in the second edition. In the first edition there is no break in the outline of the right shoulder.
[Dodgson 1911, 317]
pageContext.dimensions:
Sheet: 42.2 x 31.2 cm 
Borderlines: 28.3 x 20.4 cm
[Staatliche Kunstsammlung, Dresden, revised 2018]
pageContext.inscription:
Top: 'Luthcrus'
Below:
Quesitus toties, toties tibi Rhoma petitus/En ego per Christum viuo Lutherus adhuc/ Vna mihi spes est, quo non fraudabor, Iesus/ Hunc mihi dum teneam, perfida Rhoma vale.

pageContext.markings: Hand and text written in red chalk in margin

additionalTextInformation.text:
Two editions of the woodcut. The earlier reproduced by Lippmann is in Dresden; fine impression with broad margins; sheet size: 442 x 312; old inscription in verse, in red chalk, running round the woodcut. It has above the portrait only the name ‘Lutherus’ (sic), and beneath it the four verses´, with different orthography. This edition must have appeared before Luther’s final return to Wittenberg, to which allusion is made in the second edition. In the first edition there is no break in the outline of the r. shoulder.
[Dodgson 1911, 317]

An early print in the Prints and Drawing Department in Dresden, which only has the name 'Lutherus' above the portrait and below the two couplets: Quaesitus-vale. 
[Schuchardt 1871,vol. III, 254, No. 179]
